choices.text: PMMA bone cement used for gap filling

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic osteomyelitis was treated as shown in the picture. What procedure is done here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows antibiotic-loaded bone cement beads used for the treatment of chronic osteomyelitis.

  • When chronic osteomyelitis is treated surgically with sequestrectomy and saucerization, sometimes a large cavity is created. Such a cavity can harbour infections and cause the recurrence of osteomyelitis. In order to prevent this, we keep these antibiotic-loaded PMMA (bone cement beads). This serves 2 purposes:
    1. It fills up the cavity and prevents the collection of fluids.
    2. It releases antibiotics, which will have a local microbicidal effect.

Explanation of other options:

Open reduction internal fixation (Option A): Involves fixation of fractures, not appropriate in an active infective cavity.

Sacrerization with bone grafting (Option B): Involves debridement and defect filling, but not with antibiotic beads.

PMMA bone cement used for gap filling (Option C): PMMA may be used alone as filler, but the key here is antibiotic loading for infection control.

Key Takeaway:

Antibiotic-loaded PMMA beads are a preferred adjunctive measure post-debridement in chronic osteomyelitis for both structural and antimicrobial benefit.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known complication of chronic osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic osteomyelitis is a long-standing infection of the bone that can lead to several complications, most of which result from persistent inflammation, necrosis, and sinus tract formation.

  • The most common complication is acute exacerbation of the infection. (Option A ruled out)
  • Long-standing discharging sinuses can undergo malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. (Option B ruled out)
  • Chronic inflammation may also trigger secondary amyloidosis due to the deposition of amyloid A protein in various tissues. (Option D ruled out)
  • However, osteosarcoma, a primary malignant tumour of bone, is not associated as a complication of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a 6-week history of dull, localised pain in the distal tibia. The pain is worse at night and not associated with fever or systemic symptoms. On examination, there is mild tenderness but no swelling or redness. X-ray reveals a well-circumscribed lytic lesion in the metaphysis with a surrounding sclerotic rim. MRI reveals a central hypointense area with a surrounding hyperintense rim on T1-weighted images. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The radiological and clinical findings described are classic for Brodie’s abscess, a subacute form of osteomyelitis.

  • Occurs in adolescents due to infection with low-virulence organisms like Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Typically affects the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly the tibia.
  • Presents with localised, dull aching pain, usually worse at night and with minimal systemic signs.
  • X-ray: Shows a well-demarcated lytic lesion with a sclerotic rim.
  • MRI T1-weighted image: Shows the penumbra sign - a hyperintense rim surrounding a hypointense centre, which is highly specific for Brodie's abscess.
  • Treatment involves surgical curettage with appropriate antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Acute osteomyelitis (Option A): Presents with fever and systemic symptoms; MRI shows diffuse marrow oedema but lacks the rim-signature lesion.

Garre's osteomyelitis (Option C): Chronic sclerosing osteomyelitis of the jaw; no lytic lesion or penumbra sign.

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option D): Shows features like sequestrum, involucrum, and sinus tracts, not a well-circumscribed lytic lesion with penumbra sign.

Key Takeaway:

The penumbra sign on MRI is a specific imaging feature of Brodie's abscess, which presents as a subacute, localised metaphyseal lesion in adolescents.

choices.text: Can be used continuously or intermittently

questions.text: Which of the following regarding Negative pressure wound therapy is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) is not contraindicated in osteomyelitis; in fact, it is often used as an adjunct to improve wound healing after surgical debridement.

  • NPWT (Vacuum-assisted closure) is a technique that applies controlled subatmospheric pressure to a wound.
  • Standard pressure used: 50-125 mm Hg, not 30 mm Hg.
  • Mechanism: Removes exudate, promotes angiogenesis, and stimulates granulation tissue formation.
  • Used in both intermittent and continuous modes based on wound type and clinical response.
  • Helps in reducing bacterial load and wound size.
  • Contraindications include: presence of necrotic tissue, eschar, malignancy in the wound, or exposed blood vessels or nerves.

Key Takeaway:

Negative pressure wound therapy is not contraindicated in osteomyelitis and may aid post-debridement healing.

questions.text: False regarding TB osteomyelitis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tubercular osteomyelitis is characterised by minimal or absent periosteal reaction due to its indolent, chronic nature.

  • Tuberculosis of bone is always secondary to a primary pulmonary or extrapulmonary TB focus. (Option B ruled out)
  • Sequestrum formation is less common compared to pyogenic osteomyelitis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Chronic inflammatory response with granulomatous inflammation and caseation necrosis is seen. (Option D ruled out)
  • Severe periosteal reaction is typically absent-this finding helps differentiate it from pyogenic osteomyelitis.

Periosteal Reaction in Bone Infections:

questions.text:
A 45-year-old diabetic male presents with persistent pain and swelling in his right leg, 2 months after undergoing external fixation for an open tibial fracture. He now reports continuous purulent discharge from the surgical site, low-grade fever, and generalised fatigue. On examination, there is a draining sinus over the midshaft of the tibia with surrounding erythema and tenderness. Investigations reveal elevated ESR and CRP. X-ray of the leg shows periosteal reaction and cortical lucencies suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.
Which of the following is the most common cause of a non-healing sinus in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The persistence of a sinus in chronic osteomyelitis is most commonly due to a sequestrum, which serves as a nidus for infection and impairs healing.

  • A sequestrum is a devitalized piece of bone that harbours infection and is isolated from the vascular system.
  • Antibiotics and immune responses are ineffective unless the sequestrum is removed surgically.
  • The sinus usually tracks to the location of the sequestrum.
  • Unless removed, it perpetuates chronic inflammation and discharge.
  • Complete eradication of infection typically requires debridement and removal of the sequestrum.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple surgeries (Option A): Can contribute to infection risk, but not the most consistent cause of a non-healing sinus.

Diabetes (Option C): Impairs wound healing but is a risk factor, not the primary mechanical cause of sinus persistence.

Resistant organism (Option D): May delay healing, but surgical debridement and targeted therapy can still lead to resolution if sequestrum is absent.

Key Takeaway:
A sequestrum is the most common cause of a non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis and must be surgically removed for healing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with an acute onset of pain, swelling, and inability to move his right knee for the past 2 days. He has a high-grade fever, and the joint is held in slight flexion. The area is warm, tender, and erythematous with marked restriction of movement. Laboratory results show elevated WBC count, ESR, and CRP. Septic arthritis is suspected. What is the best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aspiration of the joint (arthrocentesis) is the most definitive diagnostic procedure in suspected septic arthritis.

  • It provides direct access to joint fluid for analysis, including cell count, Gram stain, culture and sensitivity.
  • Arthrocentesis is the test of choice when a septic arthritis is suspected.
  • On aspiration, if there is pus, it helps in 4 ways
    1. Confirm the diagnosis of septic arthritis
    2. We can plan for an immediate surgery
    3. We can send a sample for culture and sensitivity early
    4. Pain relief for the patient

Explanation of other options:

MRI scan (Option A): Sensitive for early detection of joint effusion and adjacent osteomyelitis, but cannot replace synovial fluid analysis.

Arthroscopy (Option B): Useful for lavage and debridement, but diagnostic aspiration is quicker, cheaper, and done first.

Blood culture (Option C): May support the diagnosis, but positive yield is lower than from joint fluid culture.

Key Takeaway:

Arthrocentesis is the gold standard test to confirm septic arthritis and should be performed promptly in all suspected cases.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, right hip pain and decreased appetite for 3 days. O/E she has fullness in Scarpa's triangle, hip is flexed, abducted and externally rotated and absent movements in the hip. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with FABER deformity of the hip, high-grade fever, and complete restriction of joint movements is most likely suffering from septic arthritis.

  • The FABER position (Flexion, Abduction, External Rotation) is a postural adaptation to minimise intracapsular pressure in septic arthritis.
  • Complete absence of movement (both active and passive) is characteristic of septic arthritis.
  • Systemic symptoms such as fever, anorexia, and lethargy further support an infectious aetiology.
  • Transient synovitis may present with similar limb posture but typically has low-grade or no fever, and only the terminal range of motion is restricted.

Explanation of other options:

Acute osteomyelitis (Option B): May present with fever and localised limb pain, but does not cause FABER deformity or complete restriction of hip joint motion.

Transient synovitis (Option C): Causes mild discomfort and partial restriction, but systemic signs are absent or minimal.

Anterior dislocation of the hip (Option D): Rare in children without trauma; presents acutely but without systemic symptoms or fever.

Key Takeaway:

FABER posture + high fever + immobile hip in a child strongly suggests septic arthritis.

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the hip in an infant
Causes the telescoping of the hip
Septic arthritis of the hip in children
Causes fibrous ankylosis of the hip

questions.text: Which of the following statement about Tom Smith's arthritis is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tom Smith's arthritis produces an unstable hip and not fibrous ankylosis
  • Tom Smith's arthritis is the septic arthritis of the hip in infants (<1year)
  • It is dangerous as it is fast progressing and very destructive
  • If not treated early with surgery, it can cause chondrolysis of the entire femoral head. Such children will have a limp throughout their lives
  • Symptoms - Pain, unable to move the limb, fever
  • Surgical emergency - so treated with arthrotomy as early as possible
  • Complication
    • Destruction of the proximal femoral epiphysis
    • Unstable hip
  • Features of an unstable hip
    • Shortening
    • Hypermobility of the hip
    • Trendelenburg sign
    • Telescoping of the hip

Explanation of other options:

Septic arthritis of the hip in an infant (Option A): Classic definition of Tom Smith's arthritis.

Causes telescoping of the hip (Option B): Due to loss of normal bony architecture and joint instability.

Septic arthritis of the hip in children (Option C): Term used for infants and young children; this is a broader, correct statement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male presents with persistent pain and swelling in his right tibia, 2 months after an open tibial fracture treated with external fixation. He reports purulent discharge from the surgical site, low-grade fever, and fatigue. Examination reveals erythema and a draining sinus over the mid-tibia. The area is tender, with minimal soft tissue coverage. ESR and CRP are elevated. X-ray reveals periosteal reaction and areas of cortical lucency. Which of the following is the most common cause of a non-healing sinus in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A retained sequestrum acts as a persistent nidus of infection, preventing complete healing and causing a chronic discharging sinus.

  • Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone separated from the living bone during osteomyelitis and is poorly penetrated by antibiotics or immune cells.
  • It remains infected and promotes chronic discharge through a sinus tract until surgically removed.
  • Clinical features of chronic osteomyelitis include a discharging sinus, pain, local warmth, and radiological findings such as periosteal reaction and sequestrum.
  • ESR and CRP are typically raised but nonspecific.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple surgeries (Option A): Increases risk, but is not the primary cause of chronic sinus formation.

Diabetes (Option C): A predisposing factor due to impaired immunity and vascularity, but not the direct cause of sinus.

Resistant organism (Option D): May complicate healing, but without a sequestrum, the sinus may still resolve with appropriate therapy.

Key Takeaway:

Sequestrum formation is the most common cause of persistent sinus in chronic osteomyelitis and often requires surgical removal for definitive treatment.

choices.text: Pain on palpation of the flexor tendon
Pain on passive stretching of the finger

questions.text: All are part of the Kanavel cardinal signs of flexor tenosynovitis except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kanavel's signs are classic features used to diagnose suppurative flexor tenosynovitis, a surgical emergency.

  • Kanavel cardinal signs are: (Other options are ruled out)
    1. Fusiform swelling of the finger
    2. Flexed attitude of the finger
    3. Tenderness over the flexor tendon
    4. Pain on attempted passive extension
  • Capillary refill time is unrelated to the diagnosis of tendon sheath infection and is not among the diagnostic signs.
  • Early diagnosis and prompt antibiotic plus surgical treatment are essential to prevent tendon necrosis and contracture.

Key Takeaway:

Kanavel's signs do not include vascular parameters like capillary refill time; they are localised to posture, tenderness, swelling, and pain on movement.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paronychia is a superficial bacterial infection of the nail fold, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Presents with redness, swelling, and tenderness at the edge of the nail.
  • Often triggered by nail biting or rough trimming.
  • Referred to colloquially as 'run-around infection'.
  • If an abscess forms, incision and drainage are the mainstay of treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Felon (Option A): Infection of the pulp space of the distal finger, not the nail fold. Characterised by throbbing pain and tense swelling.

Onycholysis (Option C): Painless separation of the nail plate from the nail bed, non-infectious and irrelevant to this clinical image.

Herpetic Whitlow (Option D): Caused by HSV infection, with grouped vesicles on the distal finger, no tender swelling at the nail fold.

Key Takeaway:

Paronychia is diagnosed by localised tenderness and swelling at the nail fold, unlike herpetic whitlow, which shows vesicles, or felon, which affects the deeper pulp space.

choices.text: Primary TB of the spine is common
The Cervical spine is the commonest site
Active disease has a better prognosis than healed disease
Dry diseases have a better prognosis than wet diseases

questions.text: True about TB spine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In spinal tuberculosis, active (wet) disease is associated with better outcomes because the infection is in the exudative phase, allowing for effective antibiotic penetration and healing.

  • Spinal TB is always secondary, most commonly from a pulmonary focus via hematogenous spread. (Option A ruled out)
  • The thoracolumbar junction is the most frequently affected site, not the cervical spine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Wet lesions (abscesses, granulation tissue) are associated with a better prognosis as they respond well to anti-tubercular therapy. (Option D ruled out)
  • Healed disease, especially with bony fusion and deformity (e.g., kyphosis), has poorer functional outcomes and risks neurological complications.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the treatment of TB spine except
questions.solution:
Right-sided anterolateral decompression is avoided in spinal tuberculosis due to the risk of injury to vital structures like the inferior vena cava, which lies to the right of the vertebral column.

  • Middle path regimen (Indian concept): Combines prolonged ATT with selective surgical intervention. (Option A ruled out)
  • Hong Kong operation: Radical anterior debridement + spinal fusion- proven effective for TB spine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Spinal orthosis (brace): Often advised for mechanical support, especially in early stages with minimal deformity or instability. (Option C ruled out)
  • Left-sided anterolateral decompression is the standard surgical approach to access the spine safely, avoiding major vascular structures on the right.

Key Takeaway:

Spinal TB is approached surgically via the left anterolateral side to avoid injuring the inferior vena cava; the right-sided approach is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with back pain, weight loss and evening rise of temperature for the last 3 months. His X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic radiographic triad of vertebral end plate destruction, disc space narrowing, and involvement of two adjacent vertebrae strongly suggests spinal tuberculosis (Pott's disease).

  • Tuberculosis typically spreads via the bloodstream to adjacent vertebrae and the intervening disc, which gets secondarily involved.
  • Common clinical findings include chronic back pain, constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss), and paraspinal abscesses (often seen on MRI).
  • Unlike metastasis or myeloma, TB involves the disc space early, and unlike ankylosing spondylitis, it leads to vertebral destruction, not syndesmophyte formation.

Explanation of other options:

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option A): Typically affects long bones; spinal involvement is rare and usually isolated to one vertebra.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option B): Characterised by bamboo spine, syndesmophytes, and no disc destruction.

Multiple myeloma (Option D): Causes vertebral collapse but spares disc space; usually involves non-contiguous vertebrae.

Key Takeaway:

Destruction of adjacent vertebral end plates with disc space narrowing on imaging is pathognomonic of spinal TB.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with chronic mid-back pain, progressive lower limb weakness, and recent difficulty in bladder control. He has a history of weight loss and evening rise of temperature for 4 months. X-ray spine shows destruction of adjacent vertebrae with loss of disc space and angular kyphosis. Which of the following is not a recognised complication of spinal tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bony ankylosis is the natural outcome of healing in spinal TB and is not considered a complication- rather, it represents resolution.

  • Complications of spinal TB include:
    • Paraplegia (early or late due to cord compression)
    • Psoas abscess from the anterior spread of infection
    • Kyphotic deformity from vertebral collapse
  • Bony ankylosis occurs during healing as the vertebral bodies fuse; it stabilises the spine and halts progression.

Explanation of other options:

Paraplegia (Option A): Classical complication-due to abscess, granulation tissue, or deformity compressing the cord.

Psoas abscess (Option B): Common in lumbar TB due to anterior spread along muscle planes.

Kyphosis (Option D): Common outcome of vertebral collapse, especially in the thoracic spine.

Key Takeaway:

Bony ankylosis is a healing response, not a complication, in spinal TB.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of early-onset paraplegia in TB spine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Internal gibbus (bony ridge formed by collapsed vertebral body) develops after vertebral destruction and deformity, and is a known cause of late-onset paraplegia, not early onset.

  • Early-onset paraplegia usually occurs within 2 years of disease and is due to:
    • Inflammatory tissue (granulation, caseous material) (Option A, D ruled out)
    • Pus/abscess formation (Option C ruled out)
    • Oedema or sequestrum compressing the cord
  • Late-onset paraplegia occurs years later due to mechanical compression from deformity (internal gibbus) or vascular compromise.

The earliest neurological signs of TB paraplegia are upper motor neuron (UMN) signs, which include:

  • Extensor plantar response (Babinski sign)
  • Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes
  • Ankle clonus

These signs may be present even before the patient becomes aware of any motor weakness.
Hence, all patients with TB spine should be actively screened for UMN signs to detect early cord involvement.

Key Takeaway:

Internal gibbus is a late complication of spinal TB, causing delayed neurological deficit, not part of the early paraplegia causes.

questions.text: All of the following are variants or types of osteoarticular tuberculosis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pott's fracture refers to a traumatic bimalleolar ankle fracture and has no relation to tuberculosis. It is often confused due to its phonetic similarity with Pott's disease, which refers to tuberculosis of the spine.

  • Caries sicca: A dry form of TB of the shoulder, characterised by wasting, pain, and stiffness without much swelling. (Option A ruled out)
  • Spina ventosa: Tuberculous dactylitis- expansile lesion of short bones (usually of the hand) in children. (Option B ruled out)
  • Poncet's disease: A reactive polyarthritis seen in patients with active TB elsewhere, especially in developing countries; the joints are sterile. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Only Pott's fracture is not related to osteoarticular TB. Don't confuse it with Pott's disease, which is TB of the spine.

choices.text: Emergency surgery and drainage of the abscess
Apply middle path regime: start ATT and proceed to surgery
Apply middle path regime: start ATT and monitor
Elective surgery with ALD and spinal fixation

questions.text: A 50-year-old male on walker support presents with back pain and weakness of both lower limbs for 1 month. MRI reveals a TB spine with abscess compressing the spinal cord. Next line of action is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In India, spinal TB is managed with the Middle Path Regime, which avoids immediate surgery unless specific neurological red flags are present.

  • All patients with TB paraplegia are first started on ATT and advised bed rest and given a spine brace. These patients are monitored for improvement. Patients who improve on ATT are continued on it. Those who are not improving are treated with surgery.
  • Indications of surgery in the middle path regime are
    1. Bowel and bladder involvement
    2. Worsening of paraplegia while on ATT
    3. Appearance of a new neurological deficit while on treatment
    4. No improvement in paraplegia even after 3-4 weeks of ATT
  • In this question, the patient does not have any bowel or bladder symptoms, so he is started on ATT and monitored.

Explanation of other options:

Emergency surgery (Option A): Reserved for rapid deterioration or cauda equina, not indicated here.

Start ATT + Surgery (Option B): Not appropriate unless there are complications.

Elective surgery (Option D): Surgery is not the first-line unless the criteria for failure of conservative therapy are met.

Key Takeaway:

Start ATT and monitor is the first line in TB paraplegia without red flags-this is the core of the Middle Path Regime.

questions.text: Which of the following marked areas is the most common site of origin of TB hip?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hip joint is a common site for osteoarticular tuberculosis. Among the potential sites of initial infection:

  • The roof of the acetabulum (A) is the most frequent primary focus due to its rich vascular supply.
  • Infection may later spread to involve the femoral head (B), capsule, and surrounding soft tissues.
  • The greater trochanter (C) and Babcock's triangle (D) are less commonly primary sites.

Early recognition is crucial as delayed diagnosis can lead to joint destruction and deformity.

Key Takeaway:

The roof of the acetabulum is the most common initial site of TB infection in the hip joint.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with chronic left hip pain and progressive difficulty in walking for 6 months. Examination reveals flexion and adduction deformity. X-ray pelvis shows destruction of the femoral head with enlargement and deepening of the acetabulum, giving a 'pestle-in-mortar' appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The 'mortar and pestle' appearance is a characteristic late radiological feature of advanced TB hip. It results from:

  • Destruction and deformity of the femoral head (pestle)
  • Widening and deepening of the acetabulum (mortar)

This occurs due to prolonged inflammation, bone erosion, and cartilage destruction by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Explanation of other options:

AVN femoral head (Option A): Shows segmental collapse of the femoral head but no acetabular widening.

Tom Smith's arthritis (Option B): Seen in infants; presents with destruction of the femoral head but not the classic 'mortar and pestle' appearance.

Femoroacetabular impingement (Option D): Causes mechanical conflict, not associated with gross bony destruction or radiographic features like those in TB.

Key Takeaway:

The 'mortar and pestle' appearance is a classic sign of advanced tubercular hip arthritis, indicating significant joint destruction.
